text.content: Business intelligence is the activity which contributes to the growth of any company

How does it work?

text.content: Data collected from various sources & stored in various databases cannot be directly visualized

What is a Data Warehouse?

text.content: A central location where consolidated data from multiple locations are stored

rich_text.plain_text: A central location where consolidated data from multiple locations are stored

text.content: Data warehouse is maintained separately from an organization's operational database

rich_text.plain_text: Data warehouse is maintained separately from an organization's operational database

text.content: End users access it whenever any information is needed

rich_text.plain_text: End users access it whenever any information is needed

text.content: Data warehouse is like a relational database designed for analytical needs

text.content: What are the advantages of DW?

Faster and more accurate
Properties of a DW

text.content: Subject-oriented: Data is categorized and stored by business subject rather than by application

rich_text.plain_text: Subject-oriented: Data is categorized and stored by business subject rather than by application

text.content: Integrated: Data on a given subject is collected from disparate sources and stored in a single place

rich_text.plain_text: Integrated: Data on a given subject is collected from disparate sources and stored in a single place

text.content: Time-variant: Data is stored as a series of snapshots, each representing a period of time

rich_text.plain_text: Time-variant: Data is stored as a series of snapshots, each representing a period of time

text.content: Non-volatile: Typically data in the data warehouse is not updated or deleted

rich_text.plain_text: Non-volatile: Typically data in the data warehouse is not updated or deleted

rich_text.plain_text: ETL (Extract, Transform & Load)

text.content:
ETL is the process of extracting the data from various sources, transforming this data to meet your requirement and
then loading it into a target DW

ETL is the process of extracting the data from various sources, transforming this data to meet your requirement and
then loading it into a target DW
Data Mart

text.content: Smaller version of DW which deals with single subject

rich_text.plain_text: Smaller version of DW which deals with single subject

text.content: It's focused on one area. Hence, they draw data from a limited number of sources

rich_text.plain_text: It's focused on one area. Hence, they draw data from a limited number of sources

Dependent Data Mart

Independent Data Mart

Schemas

text.content: A schema gives the local description of entire DB

rich_text.plain_text: A schema gives the local description of entire DB

text.content:
It gives details about the constraints placed on the tables, key values present & how the key values are linked
between the different tables

rich_text.plain_text:
It gives details about the constraints placed on the tables, key values present & how the key values are linked
between the different tables

text.content: A database uses relational model, while a data warehouse uses star, snowflake and fact constellation schema

rich_text.plain_text: A database uses relational model, while a data warehouse uses star, snowflake and fact constellation schema
Star Schema

text.content: Each dimension in a star schema is represented with one-dimensional table and fact table is at the center

Federated Database System
What is a federated database?

text.content: Logical association of independent database that provides a single, integrated, coherent view.

rich_text.plain_text: Logical association of independent database that provides a single, integrated, coherent view.

text.content: Federation also provide a cohesive, unified view of data derived from multiple sources.

rich_text.plain_text: Federation also provide a cohesive, unified view of data derived from multiple sources.
Characteristics of Federate Database System

text.content:
Transparency: Federated databases masks from the user difference, idiosyncrasies, and implementations of underlying
data sources

rich_text.plain_text:
Transparency: Federated databases masks from the user difference, idiosyncrasies, and implementations of underlying
data sources

text.content: Heterogeneity of data sources: Heterogeneity is the degree of differentiation in the various data sources.

rich_text.plain_text: Heterogeneity of data sources: Heterogeneity is the degree of differentiation in the various data sources.

text.content:
Extensibility and openness of the federation: In a federated system, new sources may be needed to meet the changing
needs of the users' business.

rich_text.plain_text:
Extensibility and openness of the federation: In a federated system, new sources may be needed to meet the changing
needs of the users' business.

text.content: Autonomy for data sources: Federated database does not disturb the local operation of an existing data source.

rich_text.plain_text: Autonomy for data sources: Federated database does not disturb the local operation of an existing data source.

text.content: Data integration: Federated database system can integrate data from different procotols, DBMS, using wrapper

rich_text.plain_text: Data integration: Federated database system can integrate data from different procotols, DBMS, using wrapper
Benefits of Federated Database

text.content: Offer an alternative to merge database together

rich_text.plain_text: Offer an alternative to merge database together

text.content: Help programmers avoid the tight coupling of application

rich_text.plain_text: Help programmers avoid the tight coupling of application

text.content: Applications only need to be connected to the federal database

rich_text.plain_text: Applications only need to be connected to the federal database
DocumentDB
Row-Oriented Database

text.content: Tables are stored as rows in disk

rich_text.plain_text: Tables are stored as rows in disk

text.content: A single block io read the table fetches multiple rows with their columns

rich_text.plain_text: A single block io read the table fetches multiple rows with their columns

text.content: More IOs are required to find a particular row in the table

rich_text.plain_text: More IOs are required to find a particular row in the table
Column-Oriented Database

text.content: Tables are stored as columns in disk

rich_text.plain_text: Tables are stored as columns in disk

text.content: A single block io read the table fetches multiple columns with their rows

rich_text.plain_text: A single block io read the table fetches multiple columns with their rows

text.content: Less IOs are required to find a particular row in the table

rich_text.plain_text: Less IOs are required to find a particular row in the table
Pros and Cons
Row-Based
Optimal for read/write
OLTP
Compression, aggregation is not efficient
Efficient queries with multi-columns
Column-Based
Slow Write
OLAP
Compression, aggregation is efficient
Inefficient queries with multi-columns
NoSQL Databases

text.content: Relational Databases scale vertically, and NoSQL scale horizontally

rich_text.plain_text: Relational Databases scale vertically, and NoSQL scale horizontally
It's schema-less and non-relational

text.content: Uses for cashing, pub/sub, leaderboards, etc.

rich_text.plain_text: Uses for cashing, pub/sub, leaderboards, etc.
Tradeoff between schema-less and joins

text.content: Good for time-series data, historical records, high-write but low-read

rich_text.plain_text: Good for time-series data, historical records, high-write but low-read

text.content: Graph Databases are used for graphs, knowledge, recommendation, etc.

rich_text.plain_text: Graph Databases are used for graphs, knowledge, recommendation, etc.

text.content: Data sources are extracted, transformed, Loaded to a data warehouse

STREAM system(~2003)

text.content: kSQL system: kafka as the engine started as a project in LinkedIn

Stream Data Types
Stream to relation

text.content: Relation R(t) is specified as a window over stream S

rich_text.plain_text: Relation R(t) is specified as a window over stream S
Tuple-based sliding window: S [Rows N]

text.content: R(t) contains N tuples from S with the highest timestamps

rich_text.plain_text: R(t) contains N tuples from S with the highest timestamps
Time-based sliding window: S [Range T]

text.content: R(t) contains tuples from S starting from Now() - T

rich_text.plain_text: R(t) contains tuples from S starting from Now() - T

text.content: Partitioned sliding window: S [Partition by A1,A2,... Rows N]

rich_text.plain_text: Partitioned sliding window: S [Partition by A1,A2,... Rows N]

text.content: Separate windows for each value combination in A1,A2,...

rich_text.plain_text: Separate windows for each value combination in A1,A2,...
Relation to stream

text.content: Istream(R): R's inserted tuples with insertion timestamp

rich_text.plain_text: Istream(R): R's inserted tuples with insertion timestamp

text.content: Dstream(R): R's deleted tuples with deletion timestamp

rich_text.plain_text: Dstream(R): R's deleted tuples with deletion timestamp

text.content: Rstream(R): R's inserted tuples with current timestamp

rich_text.plain_text: Rstream(R): R's inserted tuples with current timestamp
Query Processing

text.content: Input query is compiled into continuous query plan

rich_text.plain_text: Input query is compiled into continuous query plan

text.content: Query plan is composed from standard operators

rich_text.plain_text: Query plan is composed from standard operators

text.content: Operators exchange tuple additions and deletions(Streams - additions, Relations - addition and deletions)

rich_text.plain_text: Operators exchange tuple additions and deletions(Streams - additions, Relations - addition and deletions)

Join Algorithm
Tuple addition/deletion in input 1 queue

text.content: Extract join key from added queue

rich_text.plain_text: Extract join key from added queue

text.content: Probe hash table of input 2 with key

rich_text.plain_text: Probe hash table of input 2 with key

text.content: Add/delete resulting join tuples to output

rich_text.plain_text: Add/delete resulting join tuples to output
Update synopsis(hash table for input 1)

graph LR

Minimizing Space Requirements

text.content: Very important for Stream DBs(it's size is unbounded)

rich_text.plain_text: Very important for Stream DBs(it's size is unbounded)

text.content: Eliminate redundant data by synopsis sharing(especially in pub/sub)

rich_text.plain_text: Eliminate redundant data by synopsis sharing(especially in pub/sub)

text.content: Exploit constraints to prune unnecessary data

rich_text.plain_text: Exploit constraints to prune unnecessary data

text.content: Shrink intermediate results via optimized scheduling

rich_text.plain_text: Shrink intermediate results via optimized scheduling
Synopsis Sharing

text.content: Synopses of operators in same plan often overlap

rich_text.plain_text: Synopses of operators in same plan often overlap
Storing synopses separately means redundancy

text.content: Instead: global synopses with operator-specific views

rich_text.plain_text: Instead: global synopses with operator-specific views

text.content: Can extend to merge synopses of different plans

rich_text.plain_text: Can extend to merge synopses of different plans
Constraint Types
Referential integrity k-constraint
Refers to key-foreign key joins

text.content: Delay at most k between matching tuples arriving

rich_text.plain_text: Delay at most k between matching tuples arriving
Ordered-arrival k-constraint

text.content: Stream elements at least k tuple apart are sorted

rich_text.plain_text: Stream elements at least k tuple apart are sorted
Clustered-arrival k-constraint

text.content: Elements with same key can be at most k tuples apart

rich_text.plain_text: Elements with same key can be at most k tuples apart

text.content: These can exploit each constraint for dropping tuples in certain scenarios

rich_text.plain_text: These can exploit each constraint for dropping tuples in certain scenarios
Scheduling Policies

text.content: We have flexibility to decide when to invoke operators

rich_text.plain_text: We have flexibility to decide when to invoke operators

text.content: Scheduling policy may influence queue sizes

rich_text.plain_text: Scheduling policy may influence queue sizes

text.content: FIFO: Fully process tuple batches in the order of arrival

rich_text.plain_text: FIFO: Fully process tuple batches in the order of arrival

text.content: Greedy: invoke operator discarding most tuples

rich_text.plain_text: Greedy: invoke operator discarding most tuples
Mix: combine a=operators into chains

text.content:
graph LR
A[Input 1] --> B[Operator 1 with Selectivity:0.2]
B --> C[Intermediate Result]
C --> D[Operator 2]
D --> E[Output]

graph LR

D --> E[Output]
Approximation

text.content: Load Shedding: drop tuples to save overheads

rich_text.plain_text: Load Shedding: drop tuples to save overheads

text.content: Can approximate aggregates based on samples

rich_text.plain_text: Can approximate aggregates based on samples

text.content: Try to balance impact over all aggregates

rich_text.plain_text: Try to balance impact over all aggregates
Reducing synopses size: save memory

text.content: Often reduces output size of following operators with potential drawback

rich_text.plain_text: Often reduces output size of following operators with potential drawback
Apache Kafka Overview

text.content: Kafka is a java-based, distributed stream processing engine

rich_text.plain_text: Kafka is a java-based, distributed stream processing engine

text.content: Producer: Add records to different topics

rich_text.plain_text: Producer: Add records to different topics
Consumer: Subscribe to specific topics

text.content: Kafka Streams API offers filter, grouping, ... operators

rich_text.plain_text: Kafka Streams API offers filter, grouping, ... operators
Kafka Topics

text.content: Each topic corresponds to a log of ordered records and each are key-value pair

rich_text.plain_text: Each topic corresponds to a log of ordered records and each are key-value pair
Producers append to this log

text.content: Consumers receive updates for topics they subscribe to

rich_text.plain_text: Consumers receive updates for topics they subscribe to

text.content: Regular topic: delete tuples by space/time constraint

rich_text.plain_text: Regular topic: delete tuples by space/time constraint

text.content: Compacted topic: new tuples override old keys

rich_text.plain_text: Compacted topic: new tuples override old keys
Distributed Processing

text.content: Each topic is divided into partitions

rich_text.plain_text: Each topic is divided into partitions
Partitions are replicated across servers
Fault tolerance by redundancy

text.content: Allows to scale to more consumers

rich_text.plain_text: Allows to scale to more consumers

text.content: Each partition has one dedicated leader

rich_text.plain_text: Each partition has one dedicated leader
Leader access topics updates
Synchronizes with other replicas

Copying with Insertions

text.content: Need to handle insertions with a very high frequency

rich_text.plain_text: Need to handle insertions with a very high frequency

text.content: Kafka streams uses RocksDB as underlying engine

rich_text.plain_text: Kafka streams uses RocksDB as underlying engine

text.content: Highly optimized for writes, good read performance(Key idea: sequential access)

rich_text.plain_text: Highly optimized for writes, good read performance(Key idea: sequential access)

text.content: Put logs in buffer first and then make page in disk

rich_text.plain_text: Put logs in buffer first and then make page in disk
Optimize for Reads
Typically use index structure

text.content: But then insertions require random data access, which leads to slow insertions

rich_text.plain_text: But then insertions require random data access, which leads to slow insertions
Instead: Log structured Merge Tree
Log Structured Merge Tree

text.content: Maintains multiple levels containing sorted/indexed data

rich_text.plain_text: Maintains multiple levels containing sorted/indexed data

text.content: Upper levels are stored in main memory

rich_text.plain_text: Upper levels are stored in main memory

text.content: Lower levels are stored on hard disk

rich_text.plain_text: Lower levels are stored on hard disk

text.content: Constant size ratio between consecutive level

rich_text.plain_text: Constant size ratio between consecutive level

text.content: Data from one level is merged into next at overflow

rich_text.plain_text: Data from one level is merged into next at overflow

text.content: Merge operations need only sequential writes

rich_text.plain_text: Merge operations need only sequential writes
Reading LSM Tree

text.content: May have to check every level to find data

rich_text.plain_text: May have to check every level to find data

text.content: Checking each level is fast as data is sorted/indexed

rich_text.plain_text: Checking each level is fast as data is sorted/indexed
SpatialDB
Types
Types of Spatial Data

text.content: Point Data: Characterized completed by the location

rich_text.plain_text: Point Data: Characterized completed by the location

text.content: Region Data: Defined by a boundary and may have anchor location

rich_text.plain_text: Region Data: Defined by a boundary and may have anchor location
Types of Spatial Queries

text.content: Spatial range queries: show me restaurants in Seoul

rich_text.plain_text: Spatial range queries: show me restaurants in Seoul

text.content: Nearest neighbor queries: show me the nearest restaurant to my location

rich_text.plain_text: Nearest neighbor queries: show me the nearest restaurant to my location

text.content: Spatial join queries: show me the restaurants in Seoul that are Korean

rich_text.plain_text: Spatial join queries: show me the restaurants in Seoul that are Korean

Problems with B+ trees

text.content: Close points in 2D are not close in index

rich_text.plain_text: Close points in 2D are not close in index
Answering range query is inefficient

text.content: Could use one tree per dimension and merge RIDS(but various overheads)

rich_text.plain_text: Could use one tree per dimension and merge RIDS(but various overheads)
Z-ordering
Numbers each space coordinate

text.content: Close points have close numbers(counterexample Hilbert curves)

rich_text.plain_text: Close points have close numbers(counterexample Hilbert curves)
Binary representation for each coordinate
Z-ordering assigns number $a_1b_1a_2b_2...a_nb_n$

Indexing with Z-ordering
Z-ordering reduces multi-dimensional spaces to 1d

text.content: Can use standard index(e.g. B+ tree) to index Z value

rich_text.plain_text: Can use standard index(e.g. B+ tree) to index Z value
Region Quad Trees

text.content: Z ordering enables us to store points efficiently

rich_text.plain_text: Z ordering enables us to store points efficiently

text.content: Storing entire regions as set of point is inefficient

rich_text.plain_text: Storing entire regions as set of point is inefficient

text.content: Region quad trees divide space recursively into 4 quadrants

rich_text.plain_text: Region quad trees divide space recursively into 4 quadrants
Grid Files

text.content: Region quad tree partition independently of data

rich_text.plain_text: Region quad tree partition independently of data

text.content: This is not optimal if data is highly skewed

rich_text.plain_text: This is not optimal if data is highly skewed

text.content: Grid files adapt space partition to data distribution

rich_text.plain_text: Grid files adapt space partition to data distribution

text.content: More find-grained representation for high density regions

rich_text.plain_text: More find-grained representation for high density regions

text.content: Tree branches until each sub region satisfies some property!

Desiderata on Recursive Decompositions

text.content: Recursivie decomposition: specify information more robustly at a lower level of description

rich_text.plain_text: Recursivie decomposition: specify information more robustly at a lower level of description

text.content: Quadtrees and octrees are based on recursive decomposition

rich_text.plain_text: Quadtrees and octrees are based on recursive decomposition

text.content: Variations of these trees are based on:

rich_text.plain_text: Variations of these trees are based on:
Type of data represented
Property sought through decompositions
Variable or static resolution
Quad Tree Example
Constructing Region Quadtrees

text.content: Iterate through a multi-dimensional array row-by-row

rich_text.plain_text: Iterate through a multi-dimensional array row-by-row

text.content: If all 4 sub-regions exhibit desired property, merge into single node

rich_text.plain_text: If all 4 sub-regions exhibit desired property, merge into single node

text.content: $O(n^2)$ runtime complexity when $n$ is the number of points

rich_text.plain_text: $O(n^2)$ runtime complexity when $n$ is the number of points

text.content: Construction algorithm is called bottom-up neighbor finding

rich_text.plain_text: Construction algorithm is called bottom-up neighbor finding
Region Quadtree Operations

text.content: Either node is white, output is white

rich_text.plain_text: Either node is white, output is white

text.content: Both nodes are black, output is black

rich_text.plain_text: Both nodes are black, output is black

text.content: One node is black and other is gray, gray node's subtree is copied to output tree

rich_text.plain_text: One node is black and other is gray, gray node's subtree is copied to output tree

text.content: Both nodes are gray, output is gray and recurse to children in input quadtrees

rich_text.plain_text: Both nodes are gray, output is gray and recurse to children in input quadtrees

R Trees

text.content: Adaptation of B+ tree to handle spatial data

rich_text.plain_text: Adaptation of B+ tree to handle spatial data
Search key: multi-dimensional bounding box

text.content: Data Entries: (bounding box, rid) -> box is the smallest box of the data entry

rich_text.plain_text: Data Entries: (bounding box, rid) -> box is the smallest box of the data entry

text.content: Index Entries: (bounding box, pointer to child)

rich_text.plain_text: Index Entries: (bounding box, pointer to child)
Lookups in R Trees

text.content: Compute bounding box for query object. It can be single point or region

rich_text.plain_text: Compute bounding box for query object. It can be single point or region

text.content: Start at root node of R Tree

rich_text.plain_text: Start at root node of R Tree

text.content: Check children containing query object(may need to check multiple children)

rich_text.plain_text: Check children containing query object(may need to check multiple children)
Insertion in R Trees

text.content: Compute bounding box for new object

rich_text.plain_text: Compute bounding box for new object

text.content: Start at root node of R Tree

rich_text.plain_text: Start at root node of R Tree

text.content: Select child needing minimal extension for object

rich_text.plain_text: Select child needing minimal extension for object

text.content: Insert object at leaf node(may have to enlarge bounding box, may have to rebalance the tree)

rich_text.plain_text: Insert object at leaf node(may have to enlarge bounding box, may have to rebalance the tree)
Split problem

text.content: Given M+1 entries, how to split into 2 nodes?

rich_text.plain_text: Given M+1 entries, how to split into 2 nodes?

text.content: Guttman states in the original paper that there are $2^{M+1}$ possibilities and M=50 would be reasonable to assume

rich_text.plain_text: Guttman states in the original paper that there are $2^{M+1}$ possibilities and M=50 would be reasonable to assume

text.content: That means, the naive approach to look at all possible subsets and pick the best one is not practical

rich_text.plain_text: That means, the naive approach to look at all possible subsets and pick the best one is not practical
Approach with tQuadratic cost

text.content: Searches for split with smallest possible area

rich_text.plain_text: Searches for split with smallest possible area
Idea

text.content: Search for pairs of entries that would cause the largest area if placed in the same node. Then put these entries in two different nodes

rich_text.plain_text: Search for pairs of entries that would cause the largest area if placed in the same node. Then put these entries in two different nodes

text.content: Then: Considier all remaining entries and consider the one for which the increase in area has the largest possible difference between two nodes.

rich_text.plain_text: Then: Considier all remaining entries and consider the one for which the increase in area has the largest possible difference between two nodes.

text.content: This entry is assignned to the node with the smaller increase

rich_text.plain_text: This entry is assignned to the node with the smaller increase

text.content: Repeat until all entries are assigned to a node

rich_text.plain_text: Repeat until all entries are assigned to a node
R* Tree

text.content: Various subsequent publications proposed improvements of R tree via better split algorithms

rich_text.plain_text: Various subsequent publications proposed improvements of R tree via better split algorithms

text.content: The most prominent approach is described as R* Tree

rich_text.plain_text: The most prominent approach is described as R* Tree
